New Records: Mohammed Shami recorded his fourth five-wicket haul in ODIs, the most by an Indian bowler.
Shami also broke Zaheer Khan and Javagal Srinath's World Cup wicket records.
India scored 357/8, the highest team total without an individual century in the World Cup.
Shreyas Iyer scored 82 off 56 balls, and Shubman Gill was dismissed just short of a century.
Dilshan Madushanka took his maiden five-wicket haul in ODIs.
Key Match Events: India won by 302 runs, the fourth-largest margin in ODI history.
Sri Lanka's lowest all-out total in ODIs was 35, but they avoided ignominy by scoring 55.
Siraj took two wickets with his first two legal balls in ODIs.
Virat Kohli was dismissed by Madushanka, who also took Kohli's wicket earlier in the innings.
India defended 10 runs in the final over to win by 1 run, a high-pressure moment.
Pre-Game Insights: Rohit Sharma emphasized India's home advantage and the importance of not getting carried away by their performance.
Sri Lanka's coach Chris Silverwood used their defeat in the Asia Cup final as motivation.
Kusal Mendis opted to bowl first, despite India wanting to bat first.
The match was significant for both teams, with India aiming to secure a semi-finals spot and Sri Lanka fighting to stay in the tournament.
Post-Match Reflections: Rohit Sharma called the win a significant morale booster ahead of the World Cup.
Mohammed Shami was named Player of the Match for his exceptional performance.
The match saw no major announcements or retirements.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The pitch was described as challenging for bowlers with little margin for error.
The match was the latest in a series of historical comparisons and records, including Sachin Tendulkar's legacy.
The game was also significant for qualification to future tournaments, including the 2025 Champions Trophy.
